awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Study for a new design of child resistance packaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a novel medication safety cap capable of simultaneous child-resistance and adult-accessibility to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with unintentional medication overdoses by young children. Every hour a young child under the age of 6 is hospitalized, and every 12 days a child dies in the United States due to unintentional medication ingestion. Studies have shown that improper use of safety caps by adults (only partially securing the cap or leaving it off entirely) contributes to unsupervised medication ingestions by young children. The proposed safety cap would prevent access by young children while also being easy to understand and operate by older senior adults, integrate with current high- speed manufacturing and distribution systems, and be cost-competitive. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project leverages the ergonomic differences between child and adult hand sizes, with differences in human-product interaction behavior, to develop more effective child-resistant packaging for medications. Current state-of-the-art safety caps rely on strength and dexterity-based mechanisms to restrict access for young children, but these methods are also often difficult for adults to use properly. This project seeks to leverage the behavioral and mechanical product interaction differences into a safety cap and provide quantitative evidence of both senior adult accessibility and child- resistance. The expected outcomes of this Phase I project is a design that is (1) validated to function within the thresholds of child-resistance and senior adult accessibility, and (2) pass safety and regulatory measures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 2222 W GRAND RIVER AVE STE A

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Child-resistant packaging is intended to serve as a last line of defense which provides a physical barrier that restricts young children from gaining access to toxic or harmful household substances. This project's approach focused on leveraging the differences in hand sizes between children and adults, by combining principles of torque mechanics with packaging design theory, to develop a more effective paradigm for child-resistant packaging. The goal of this project was to demonstrate that a new type of child-resistant packaging could enable senior adult accessibility and simultaneous child-resistance for screw cap medication containers.  

During the course of this project, researchers measured and collected data demonstrating the capabilities of young children and senior adults to apply a twisting force to various packaging designs. It was demonstrated with a new innovative packaging design that the twisting force young children could generate was significantly reduced while adults could maintain twisting forces similar to packaging that was not child-resistant. However, it was also demonstrated that adults who frequently use non-child resistant screw cap medication containers in their own homes, using their own self-determination for how tightly to close these containers, will often close the packages with such minimum force that children could generate enough torque to open these types of packages.

It was identified that it is likely necessary to improve the package closing behavior of adults while also having methods to reduce the twisting forces that children can generate to achieve simultaneous child-resistance and broader adult accessibility. Further work needs to be done to achieve consistent closability of the innovation with adults.

Broader Impacts:

The findings that adults, using their own self-determination for how tightly to close medication containers, may often close containers with such minimum force that a young child could generate enough force to open these containers is significant for packaging design theory of child-resistant packaging. Demonstration that the differences in child and adult hand sizes can be leveraged into packaging designs that significantly reduces the torque young children can generate is also a significant outcome that can be used to enable new methodologies for developing more effective child-resistant packaging.

This NSF grant enabled underrepresented women and minorities in STEM to engage in professional development opportunities. Packaging and Mechanical Engineering faculty members at Michigan State University's Packaging Healthcare, Universal Design, Biomechanics (HUB) Lab and Mechanical Engineering's Biomechanical Design Research Laboratory (BDRL) mentored, taught, and trained graduate/undergraduate students to responsibly conduct research, test participants, collect data and manage projects. Poster presentations of this project were presented at two conferences by an undergraduate researcher. This researcher was accepted into graduate school and will also publish a research paper and her Masters' thesis in Biosystems Engineering using the data from this project. A Packaging graduate researcher conducted the packaging study for this grant and has accepted a career in industry.  All study participants (senior adults, and young children in the presence of their parents/gaurdians) were debriefed about the purpose of the study, safe storage of medication, keeping medication out of reach of children and provided educational materials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) "Up and Away" Medication Safety Program.

 


Last Modified: 09/15/2023
Modified by: Cory J Wilson
